greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Permutation of natural numbers: sequence A126441 without zeros.
comment: Values appear in the order determined by A004760(n+1)and A062383(n).
The graph of this sequence looks very elegant.
link: A. Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1596 (first 18 rows)
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
example: This can be viewed as an irregular table, where row r (>= 1) has A000041(r) elements, that is, as 1; 2,3; 4,5,7; 8,9,6,11,15; 16,17,10,19,13,23,31; etc. A125106 illustrates how each number is mapped to a partition.
mathematica: columns = 9; row[n_] := n - 2^Floor[Log2[n]]; col[0] = 0; col[n_] := If[EvenQ[n], col[n/2] + DigitCount[n/2, 2, 1], col[(n - 1)/2] + 1]; Clear[T]; T[_, _] = 0; Do[T[row[k], col[k]] = k, {k, 1, 2^columns}]; Table[DeleteCases[Table[T[n - 1, k], {n, 1, 2^(k - 1)}], 0], {k, 1, columns}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Sep 09 2017 *)
xref: Inverse: A166276. a(n) = A126441(A166274(n)). See A161919 for the version with each row sorted into ascending order.
results.author: _Alford Arnold_, Jun 23 2009
ext: Edited and extended by _Antti Karttunen_, Oct 12 2009
